      35     1421070 : static void scan_declarator_attributes(a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
      36             :                                        a_type_ptr          *p_type)
      37             : /*
      38             : Scan attributes that appear after a declarator component other than the
      39             : declarator-id.  *p_type is the type formed by the particular declarator
      40             : component being parsed.  (Because of the way types are built up through
      41             : declarators, **p_type may not be fully formed yet.  For example, the type
      42             : pointed to by a pointer type may still be NULL.)
      43             : GCC allows attributes after array and function declarators only for non-nested
      44             : declarators.  Such attributes are placed on the state->id_attributes list
      45             : (i.e., they are treated as appertaining to the declared entity, rather than to
      46             : the type formed by the declarator component as would be the case with
      47             : standard-attribute syntax).
      48             : */
      49             : {
      50     1421070 :   a_type_ptr                      type = *p_type;
      51     1421070 :   enum an_attribute_location_tag  syn_loc;
      52     1421070 :   an_attribute_ptr                attributes;
      53     1421070 :   a_boolean                       error_issued = FALSE;
      54             : 
      55             :   /* Determine the syntactic location from the type. */
      56     1421070 :   switch (skip_typerefs_not_typedefs(type)->kind) {
      57           0 :     case tk_error:
      58           0 :       expect_error();
      59             :       /* No logical attribute location can be derived for an error type.
      60             :          Ignore any attributes that come up.  (A location is still assigned
      61             :          to avoid diagnostics from compilers and tools.) */
      62           0 :       skip_over_attributes();
      63           0 :       syn_loc = al_implicit;
      64           0 :       break;
      65             :     case tk_pointer:
      66             :     case tk_ptr_to_member:
      67             :       syn_loc = al_post_ptr_or_ref;
      68             :       break;
      69        6706 :     case tk_array:
      70        6706 :       syn_loc = al_post_array;

      72     1164190 :     case tk_routine:

      74     1164190 :       break;
      75           0 :     default:
      76             :       /* This can only validly happen with GNU attributes specified as the
      77             :          first construct in a nested declarator or after an outermost
      78             :          parenthesized declarator.  In the first case, they are treated like
      79             :          specifier attributes (e.g., "int (__attribute((mode(DI))) x);" is
      80             :          treated like "int __attribute((mode(DI))) x;").  In the second case

     260           0 : a_boolean is_cfront_member_function_typedef(a_type_ptr   type_ptr,
     261             :                                             a_type_ptr   *rout_type,
     262             :                                             a_type_ptr   *class_type,
     263             :                                             a_symbol_ptr *sym)
     264             : /*
     265             : We are checking for a type entry produced by a typedef declaration like
     266             : this:
     267             : 
     268             :         typedef void A::T(int);  // Nonstandard typedef
     269             : 
     270             : (meaning "T" names a routine type for a member function of A that takes an
     271             : int argument and returning void.  Its tie to class A is indicated by having
     272             : an implicit this-param type of const-ptr-to-A).  Cfront treats "T*" as though
     273             : it had been a ptr-to-member declaration -- e.g.,
     274             : 
     275             :         T* pm = &A::f(int);      // Nonstd ptr-to-member decl
     276             : 
     277             : and
     278             : 
     279             :         void (A::*pm)(int) = &A::f(int);
     280             : 
     281             : have the very same meaning for cfront.  Although this is not part of the
     282             : language defined in the ARM, it is supported for cfront compatibility.
     283             : 
     284             : Return TRUE if this is a member function typedef.  Also return a pointer to
     285             : the function type and the class type if this is the case -- and a pointer to
     286             : the type symbol for the typedef, for use in diagnostics.
     287             : */
     288             : {
     289           0 :   a_type_ptr  tp;
     290           0 :   a_boolean   is_member_function_typedef = FALSE;

     350           0 : a_boolean restrict_qualifier_is_allowed(a_type_ptr         type,
     351             :                                         a_source_position  *error_pos)
     352             : /*
     353             : Return TRUE if type may be qualified by the "restrict" qualifier.  It may be
     354             : applied to pointer and reference types (but not pointer-to-function-type),

     356             : parameter declarations only) array types.  If a restrict qualifier is not
     357             : allowed, issue a diagnostic and return FALSE.

     402        1822 : static void check_for_restrict_qualifier_on_derived_type(
     403             :                                               a_type_ptr  new_type_ptr,
     404             :                                               a_type_ptr  *derived_type,
     405             :                                               a_type_ptr  *bottom_derived_type)
     406             : /*
     407             : *derived_type is the top of a derived type that is being constructed, and
     408             : *bottom_derived_type is the bottom, which is about to be updated to link to
     409             : new_type_ptr.  Check for the presence of improperly applied restrict
     410             : qualifier: if *bottom_derived_type is some kind of pointer or reference type
     411             : and is about to be updated to point to a function type, then the restrict
     412             : qualifier, if there is one, is invalid.  Issue a diagnostic and rewrite the
     413             : derived type to remove the restrict qualifier.
     414             : */
     415             : {
     416        1822 :   a_type_ptr            tp, prev_tp, new_tp;
     417        1822 :   a_type_qualifier_set  qualifiers;
     418             : 
     419        1822 :   if (is_function_type(new_type_ptr)) {
     420        1739 :     check_assertion(is_any_ptr_or_ref_type(*bottom_derived_type) ||
     421             :                     is_ptr_to_member_type(*bottom_derived_type));
     422             :     /* We are about to form a derived type that is pointer-to-function-type,
     423             :        reference-to-function-type, or ptr-to-member-function.  Such pointer
     424             :        types, unlike other pointer types, may not be restrict qualified.
     425             :        Go through the derived type list looking for restrict qualifier that
     426             :        applies to the pointer type. */
     427        1739 :     for (tp = *derived_type, prev_tp = NULL;
     428        1739 :          !same_entities(tp, *bottom_derived_type);
     429           0 :          prev_tp = tp, tp = underlying_type_of_derived_type(tp)) {
     430           0 :       if (tp->kind == (a_type_kind)tk_typeref) {
     431             :         /* Check for qualifiers on a typeref. */
     432           0 :         qualifiers = get_top_level_type_qualifiers(tp);
     433           0 :         tp = skip_typerefs(tp);
     434           0 :         if (same_entities(tp, *bottom_derived_type)) {
     435           0 :           if (qualifiers & TQ_RESTRICT) {
     436             :             /* A restrict qualifier was found and it applies to the pointer
     437             :                type that is going to be set to point to the function type.
     438             :                Issue a diagnostic and remove the restrict qualifier. */
     439           0 :             pos_error(ec_restrict_pointer_to_function, &error_position);
     440           0 :             if (qualifiers == TQ_RESTRICT) {
     441           0 :               new_tp = *bottom_derived_type;
     442             :             } else {
     443           0 :               new_tp = make_qualified_type(*bottom_derived_type,
     444             :                                            (qualifiers & ~TQ_RESTRICT));
     445           0 :               *bottom_derived_type = skip_typerefs(new_tp);

     709             : static
     710             : a_boolean check_invalid_use_of_special_cli_class_type(a_type_ptr         tp,

     712             : /*

     746           1 : void report_bad_return_type_qualifier(a_type_ptr          type,
     747             :                                       a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
     748             :                                       a_source_position   *diag_pos,
     749             :                                       a_boolean           *err)
     750             : /*
     751             : The given type is a qualified type used as a function return type.  Issue an
     752             : error if the qualification is invalid or a warning or remark if it is not
     753             : meaningful (e.g., the "const" in "int const f()" has no effect).  If an error
     754             : is issued, *err is set to TRUE.  For explicit return type declarations, *dps
     755             : carries information about the way the type was formed (e.g., whether qualifiers
     756             : appeared explicitly; meaningless qualification acquired through a typedef are
     757             : not diagnosed); for the implicit function return type resulting from certain
     758             : lambda constructs, dps is NULL.  Diagnostics are issued at the position given
     759             : by *diag_pos or at a position recorded in *dps (depending on the diagnostic).

     805             :          that the type qualifier is "useless" for some instantiations
     806             :          but not in general -- e.g.,
     807             :            template <class T> struct A {
     808             :              const T f();
     809             :            };
     810             :            struct X { };
     811             :            A<int> aint;     // A<int>::f returns const int (useless)
     812             :            A<X> ax;         // A<X>::f returns const X (okay)
     813             :          Do not issue a remark in this case to eliminate annoying
     814             :          warnings the user can't do anything about. */
     815             :       /* Note that this solution fails to warn on cases that are
     816             :          *always* useless, too.  If A<T>::f returned "T * const" a
     817             :          warning would always be appropriate, whatever T was replaced
     818             :          by in the instantiation.  But the representation of types
     819             :          based on template arguments will have to be improved to
     820             :          make this distinction.  When performing prototype
     821             :          instantiations, however, most such cases are in fact
     822             :          diagnosed. */
     823             :     } else {

     834     1164190 : a_boolean check_return_type(a_type_ptr          type,
     835             :                             a_decl_parse_state  *dps,

     882             : 
     883             : 
     884     2341720 : void add_to_derived_type_list(a_type_ptr          new_type_ptr,
     885             :                               a_type_ptr          *derived_type,
     886             :                               a_type_ptr          *bottom_derived_type,
     887             :                               a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
     888             :                               a_boolean           parameter_type)
     889             : /*
     890             : Add the type entry pointed to by new_type_ptr to the list of derived-type
     891             : entries pointed to by *derived_type (and whose end is pointed to by
     892             : *bottom_derived_type).  Aside from the purely mechanical issues of linking the
     893             : entries, this routine also checks to see if the resulting type is legal.  If
     894             : the type is for a parameter declaration, parameter_type is TRUE (in Sun and
     895             : GNU C++ modes this relaxes the array of abstract class check).  *dps describes
     896             : the specifiers and declarator that formed the new type.
     897             : */
     898             : {
     899     2341720 :   a_type_ptr              temp_type, prev_temp_type, tp;
     900     2341720 :   a_boolean               err = FALSE;
     901     2341720 :   a_type_kind             tkind;
     902     2341720 :   a_boolean               array_of_incomp_class_or_enum = FALSE;
     903     2341720 :   a_boolean               is_member_function_typedef = FALSE;
     904     2341720 :   a_type_ptr              mft_class_type, mft_rout_type;
     905     2341720 :   a_symbol_ptr            mft_sym;
     906             : 
     907     2341720 :   db_enter(3, "add_to_derived_type_list");
     908             : #if DEBUG
     909     2341720 :   if (debug_level >= 4 || db_flag_is_set("declarators")) {
     910           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, "At start of add_to_derived_type_list:\n");
     911           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, "  new_type_ptr = ");
     912           0 :     db_type(new_type_ptr);
     913           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, "\n");
     914           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, "  *derived_type = ");
     915           0 :     db_type(*derived_type);
     916           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, "\n");
     917           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, "  *bottom_derived_type = ");
     918           0 :     db_type(*bottom_derived_type);
     919           0 :     fprintf(f_debug, "\n");
     920             :   }  /* if */
     921             : #endif /* DEBUG */
     922             :   /* Note that while derived types are being built up, the derived-type
     923             :      entries are connected to one another from the top down, which
     924             :      means that the bottom-most derived-type entry temporarily points
     925             :      to nothing (a "partial type").  Each derived type is checked as the
     926             :      type below it is attached.  This must be done carefully, because the
     927             :      type being attached may look incomplete (its size may be zero). */
     928     2341720 :   if (*bottom_derived_type == NULL) {
     929             :     /* This is the first entry on the list.  No checking can be done yet. */
     930     1169000 :     *derived_type = new_type_ptr;
     931             :     /* We'll find the real bottom of the type below. */
     932     1169000 :     *bottom_derived_type = new_type_ptr;
     933             :   } else {
     934             :     /* The derived-type list is non-empty, so we need to check to see if
     935             :        the bottom derived type can legally be connected to the new type
     936             :        (e.g., if it's an array, can it have elements of the indicated
     937             :        type, and if it's a function, can it have a result of the indicated
     938             :        type). */
     939     1172720 :     tkind = (*bottom_derived_type)->kind;
     940     1172720 :     if (tkind == (a_type_kind)tk_error) {
     941             :       /* The bottom derived type is an error, and nothing can be attached
     942             :          to it.  Therefore, the new type is thrown away. */
     943             :     } else {
     944     1172720 :       if (any_cfront_mode()) {
     945             :         /* Check for a "member function typedef" type -- it can only be used

    1253             :          up computing sizes of types on the list.  This is necessary to
    1254             :          finish off array and pointer type entries which had dependent
    1255             :          types with unknown sizes up until now.  This happens because
    1256             :          the string of array/pointer/function types has to be built up
    1257             :          in a strange order, and sometimes a list of derived types has
    1258             :          no type at the bottom (just a NULL pointer waiting to be filled

    1326           0 : static void scan_eh_spec_type(an_exception_specification_type_ptr

    1578             : 
    1579             : 
    1580      278081 : static an_exception_specification_ptr scan_exception_specification(
    1581             :                                   a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
    1582             :                                   a_func_info_block   *func_info,
    1583             :                                   a_boolean           exception_spec_allowed,
    1584             :                                   a_boolean           is_top_level_declarator)
    1585             : /*
    1586             : Scan an exception specification, which may be empty or take one of the
    1587             : following forms:
    1588             : 
    1589             :   noexcept
    1590             :   noexcept( <expression> )
    1591             :   throw ()
    1592             :   throw ( <type-name> [, <type-name> ]... )
    1593             :   throw (...)
    1594             : 
    1595             : (The last variant, "throw (...)", is a Microsoft feature used to indicate
    1596             : explicitly that a function can throw any exception.  This is necessary for
    1597             : Microsoft compilers because they assume by default that extern "C" functions
    1598             : do not throw exceptions.)
    1599             : 
    1600             : Return a (possibly NULL) pointer to the appropriate kind of exception
    1601             : specification entry and update *func_info (describing the current function
    1602             : declarator) as needed.
    1603             : 
    1604             : Diagnostics are issued on redundant types on a list, but if this is a
    1605             : redeclaration of a routine, reconciliation with the previous throw
    1606             : specification is handled later (see check_exception_specification).
    1607             : 
    1608             : exception_spec_allowed is FALSE if this routine is called for a function
    1609             : declarator that doesn't permit exception specifications (e.g., the function
    1610             : declarator in a pointer-to-pointer-to-function declaration).
    1611             : is_top_level_declarator is TRUE if this is function is called for a function
    1612             : declarator that is the top-level declarator of a declaration (i.e., it
    1613             : actually declares a function, member function, or function template).
    1614             : */
    1615             : {
    1616      278081 :   an_exception_specification_ptr       esp = NULL;
    1617      278081 :   an_exception_specification_type_ptr  estp, other_estp, end_of_list = NULL;
    1618      278081 :   a_source_position                    type_pos;
    1619      278081 :   a_boolean                            ignoring_exception_spec = FALSE;
    1620      278081 :   a_boolean                            is_noexcept;
    1621             : 
    1622      278081 :   db_enter(4, "scan_exception_specification");
    1623      278081 :   is_noexcept = curr_token == tok_noexcept;
    1624      278081 :   if (exceptions_enabled || curr_token == tok_throw || is_noexcept) {
    1625             :     /* Update the source position for the "throw".  Even if there is no
    1626             :        "throw" this is where it would appear in the source.  If exception
    1627             :        support is not enabled but a "throw" appears, we may want to issue
    1628             :        a diagnostic, so save the source position for that case, too. */
    1629      278081 :     func_info->throw_position = pos_curr_token;
    1630             :   }  /* if */
    1631      278081 :   if (curr_token != tok_throw && !is_noexcept) {
    1632             :     /* No explicit throw specification, meaning anything may be thrown. */
    1633      260697 :     goto done;
    1634             :   }  /* if */
    1635       17384 :   if (!exceptions_enabled || !exception_spec_allowed ||
    1636             :       (microsoft_bugs && microsoft_version <= 1200 && !is_noexcept)) {
    1637             :     /* If exception-handling support is not enabled, or if this is a context
    1638             :        in which an exception specification is not allowed, or if (in some
    1639             :        Microsoft-compatibility modes) exception specifications are recognized
    1640             :        but ignored, set a flag to control the diagnostics that are put out. */
    1641           0 :     ignoring_exception_spec = TRUE;
    1642             :   }  /* if */
    1643           0 :   if (!ignoring_exception_spec ||
    1644           0 :       (is_noexcept && is_top_level_declarator && next_token() == tok_lparen &&
    1645           0 :        (is_template_dependent_context() ||
    1646           0 :         is_nonspecialized_instantiation_context()))) {
    1647             :     /* An exception specification must be recorded if it is not ignored later
    1648             :        on, but, in the case of noexcept we also want to record it so that it
    1649             :        can be instantiated later on (even though it will be ignored after that
    1650             :        instantiation). */
    1651       17384 :     esp = alloc_exception_specification();
    1652       17384 :     esp->is_noexcept = is_noexcept;
    1653             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL
    1654       17384 :     esp->source_range.start = pos_curr_token;
    1655             : #endif /* EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */
    1656             :   }  /* if */
    1657       17384 :   if (!ignoring_exception_spec) {
    1658             :     /* Exceptions are outside the "Embedded C++" subset. */
    1659       17384 :     feature_is_not_part_of_embedded_cplusplus_subset(
    1660             :                                           &pos_curr_token,
    1661             :                                           ec_exceptions_in_embedded_cplusplus);
    1662           0 :   } else if (!exception_spec_allowed) {
    1663             :     /* This is a declaration on which an exception specification is not
    1664             :        allowed. */
    1665           0 :     pos_diagnostic((!exceptions_enabled || microsoft_bugs) ?
    1666             :                        es_warning : es_discretionary_error,
    1667             :                    ec_exception_specification_not_allowed, &pos_curr_token);
    1668             :   } else if (microsoft_bugs && microsoft_version <= 1200) {
    1669             :     /* Issue a remark: Exception specifications are parsed and discarded. */
    1670             :     pos_remark(ec_exception_specification_ignored, &pos_curr_token);
    1671             :   }  /* if */
    1672       17384 :   if (is_noexcept) {
    1673        8683 :     if (next_token() != tok_lparen) {
    1674             :       /* "noexcept" without arguments. */
    1675        7841 :       if (esp != NULL) {
    1676        7841 :         esp->variant.noexcept_arg = NULL;
    1677             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL

    1853             : 
    1854     1121890 : static a_boolean is_prototyped_parameter_list_start(void)
    1855             : /*
    1856             : Return TRUE if the current token is the start of a prototyped parameter list,
    1857             : FALSE if it is the start of an old-style identifier list.  The current token
    1858             : is the first token after the opening parenthesis.  Note that the case of
    1859             : an empty parameter list, as in "int f();", is handled by the caller and
    1860             : need not be addressed here.
    1861             : */
    1862             : {
    1863     1121890 :   a_boolean    prototyped;
    1864     1121890 :   a_token_kind next_tok;
    1865             : 
    1866             :   /* The ambiguous cases start with an identifier. */
    1867     1121890 :   if (curr_token == tok_identifier) {
    1868      908993 :     if (curr_id_is_type_name(GID_NO_OPTIONS, IDS_NO_OPTIONS)) {
    1869             :       /* The identifier is a typedef symbol. */
    1870      908993 :       if (C_dialect != C_dialect_pcc) {
    1871             :         /* In ANSI and C++ mode, this must be a prototyped parameter list. */
    1872             :         prototyped = TRUE;
    1873             :       } else {
    1874             :         /* In pcc mode, it's an old-style identifier list if the
    1875             :            identifier is followed by "," or ")", and a prototyped parameter
    1876             :            list otherwise.  pcc would, of course, consider anything to
    1877             :            be an old-style identifier list. */
    1878           0 :         next_tok = next_token();
    1879           0 :         if (next_tok == tok_comma || next_tok == tok_rparen) {
    1880             :           /* A case like 
    1881             :                int f(t )     or
    1882             :                int f(t , u)
    1883             :                        ^---- must be old-style.
    1884             :           */
    1885             :           prototyped = FALSE;
    1886             :         } else {
    1887             :           /* A case like
    1888             :                int f(t x)
    1889             :                        ^---- must be prototyped.
    1890             :           */
    1891           0 :           prototyped = TRUE;
    1892             :         }  /* if */
    1893             :       }  /* if */
    1894             :     } else {
    1895             :       /* The identifier is not a typedef.  This suggests the start of an
    1896             :          old-style identifier list. */
    1897           0 :       if (C_dialect == C_dialect_pcc) {
    1898             :         /* In pcc mode, this must be an old-style identifier list. */
    1899             :         prototyped = FALSE;
    1900             :       } else {
    1901             :         /* To improve error recovery in ANSI mode for
    1902             :              int f(tt x);
    1903             :            where tt was supposed to be a typedef identifier but was not
    1904             :            declared (maybe tt is misspelled), assume a prototyped parameter
    1905             :            list if the next token is not a "," or ")". */
    1906           0 :         next_tok = next_token();
    1907           0 :         if (next_tok == tok_comma || next_tok == tok_rparen) {
    1908             :           /* A case like 
    1909             :                int f(tt )     or
    1910             :                int f(tt , u )
    1911             :                         ^---- must be old-style.
    1912             :           */
    1913             :           prototyped = FALSE;
    1914             :         } else {
    1915             :           /* A case like
    1916             :                int f(tt x)
    1917             :                         ^---- must be prototyped.
    1918             :           */
    1919           0 :           prototyped = TRUE;
    1920             :         }  /* if */
    1921             :       }  /* if */
    1922             :     }  /* if */
    1923      212893 :   } else if (is_decl_start(IDS_REAL_DECLARATOR_ALLOWED)) {

    1925             :        a declaration (but not a typedef identifier): for example, "int".
    1926             :        This must be a prototyped parameter list. */
    1927             :     prototyped = TRUE;
    1928             :   } else {
    1929             :     /* The parameter list starts with something else, meaning there's an
    1930             :        error.  In ANSI mode, assume a prototyped parameter list; in pcc
    1931             :        mode, assume an old-style identifier list.  The error will be
    1932             :        issued below. */
    1933           0 :     prototyped = (C_dialect != C_dialect_pcc);
    1934             :   }  /* if */
    1935     1121890 :   return prototyped;
    1936             : }  /* is_prototyped_parameter_list_start */

    1939             : /*ARGSUSED*/  /* "dps" is currently unused. */
    1940             : static void scan_member_function_modifiers(a_symbol_locator    *locator,
    1941             :                                            a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
    1942             :                                            a_func_info_block   *func_info)
    1943             : /*
    1944             : Scan for member function modifiers and record their presence in *func_info.
    1945             : *dps describes some syntactic properties of the current declaration.
    1946             : ("sealed", "abstract", and "override" are an ECMA C++/CLI extension also
    1947             : accepted by some Microsoft compilers in their non-CLI modes; "new" is only
    1948             : accepted in C++/CLI mode.)  "final" is accepted in later Microsoft modes.
    1949             : */
    1950             : {
    1951             :   a_boolean  accept_ms_modifiers = ms_extensions &&
    1952             :                                    (cli_or_cx_enabled ||
    1953             :                                     microsoft_version >= 1400);

    1955             :                                          microsoft_version >= 1700);

    1958             :     a_boolean  err = FALSE;

    2067             : a_boolean check_param_array_type(a_param_type_ptr   ptp,
    2068             :                                  a_source_position  *diag_pos)
    2069             : /*
    2070             : Return TRUE if the given C++/CLI parameter array is a handle to a
    2071             : one-dimensional CLI array; if not and diag_pos is non-NULL, issue a diagnostic
    2072             : at *diag_pos.
    2073             : */
    2074             : {
    2075             :   a_boolean  err = FALSE;
    2076             :   a_type_ptr param_type = ptp->type;
    2077             : 
    2078             :   if (!is_handle_type(param_type)) {
    2079             :     err = !is_error_type(param_type) && !is_template_param_type(param_type);
    2080             :   } else {
    2081             :     /* Check that the handle "points to" a C++/CLI array type. */
    2082             :     a_type_ptr  tp = type_pointed_to(param_type);
    2083             :     tp = skip_typerefs(tp);
    2084             :     if (!is_cli_array_type(tp)) {
    2085             :       err = !is_error_type(tp) && !is_template_param_type(tp);

    2087             :       /* Check that the C++/CLI array type is one-dimensional.  Template-
    2088             :          dependent dimensions are not acceptable. */
    2089             :       a_boolean unknown;
    2090             :       if (cli_array_rank(tp, &unknown) != 1) {

    2093             :              an error type to avoid surprises downstream. */

    2112             : 
    2113        2026 : void make_param_syms_invisible(a_boolean  is_invisible)
    2114             : /*
    2115             : The current scope is a function prototype scope.  Set the is_invisible flag of
    2116             : the parameter symbols in that scope to is_invisible.
    2117             : */
    2118             : {
    2119        2026 :   a_symbol_ptr  sym = scope_stack_top().pointers_block.symbols;
    2120             : 
    2121        6490 :   for (; sym != NULL; sym = sym->next_in_scope) {

    2147         146 : void check_type_with_placeholder_specifier(a_decl_parse_state  *state)
    2148             : /*
    2149             : *state describes a declaration parsing state involving a complete declarator
    2150             : that builds a type on top of an "auto" or "decltype(auto)" type specifier.
    2151             : Check that the resulting type is not an array type, and, if C++14-style
    2152             : deduced return types are not enabled, that it is not a function type without a
    2153             : trailing return type.  Also, if this is a secondary declarator, diagnose cases
    2154             : such as
    2155             :     auto f()->int, x = 0;
    2156             : where "auto" is used both to deduce a type from an initializer and to announce
    2157             : a trailing return type.
    2158             : */

    2160         146 :   a_boolean  err = FALSE, ctad_case = state->has_deducible_class_templ_args;

    2248             : 
    2249             : static void scan_trailing_return_type(a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
    2250             :                                       a_type_ptr          rout_type)
    2251             : /*
    2252             : A function declarator has just been parsed (resulting in the entry rout_type)
    2253             : and the current token is a "->".  Scan a trailing return type and update
    2254             : *rout_type and *dps accordingly (*dps describes the current declaration).
    2255             : Diagnostics are issued if the function declarator does not in fact allow for a
    2256             : trailing return type (e.g., because the type specifier was not "auto").  This
    2257             : routine is also called for the trailing return type of a lambda declarator.
    2258             : */
    2259             : {
    2260             :   a_decl_parse_state             trt_dps;
    2261             :   a_boolean                      err = FALSE;
    2262             : 
    2263             :   check_assertion(curr_token == tok_arrow);
    2264             :   if (dps->is_lambda || dps->is_deduction_guide) {
    2265             :     /* No special syntax checks are needed. */
    2266             :   } else if (!dps->auto_type_specifier_seen ||
    2267             :              dps->has_deducible_class_templ_args) {
    2268             :     /* Something like "int ()->int" or "decltype(auto) f()->void". */
    2269             :     pos_error(ec_trailing_return_type_requires_auto, &error_position);
    2270             :     err = TRUE;
    2271             :   } else if (dps->in_nested_declarator) {
    2272             :     /* Something like "auto (()->int)". */
    2273             :     pos_error(ec_trailing_return_type_in_nested_declarator, &error_position);
    2274             :     err = TRUE;
    2275             :   } else if (dps->type != dps->auto_type) {
    2276             :     /* Something like "auto *()->int". */
    2277             :     pos_error(ec_trailing_return_type_function_without_simple_auto,
    2278             :               &dps->declarator_start_pos);
    2279             :     err = TRUE;
    2280             :   }  /* if */
    2281             :   /* Any leading "auto" did not represent a deduced type after all. */

    2299             :     trt_dps.auto_type_allowed = TRUE;
    2300             :   }  /* if */
    2301             :   if (parameters_visible_late) {
    2302             :   /* In some GNU C++ modes, parameter symbols are marked invisible until a
    2303             :      definition (if any) is seen.  The corresponding GCC compilers do not

    2342      278081 : static void cplusplus_function_declarator_trailer(

    2356             :                                    a_decl_pos_block    *decl_pos_block)
    2357             : /*

    2366      278081 :   a_routine_type_supplement_ptr   rtsp = rout_type->variant.routine.extra_info;

    2519             :       this_class = parent_type;

    2731     1164190 : void function_declarator(a_decl_parse_state  *state,
    2732             :                          a_decl_flag_set     di_flags,
    2733             :                          a_type_ptr          *new_type_ptr,
    2734             :                          a_func_info_block   *func_info,
    2735             :                          a_symbol_locator    *locator,
    2736             :                          a_type_ptr          parent_type,
    2737             :                          a_boolean           is_nonstatic_member,
    2738             :                          a_boolean           is_constructor,
    2739             :                          a_boolean           is_static_constructor,
    2740             :                          a_boolean           is_destructor,
    2741             :                          a_boolean           is_finalizer,
    2742             :                          a_boolean           disallow_default_args,
    2743             :                          a_boolean           disallow_exception_spec,
    2744             :                          a_decl_pos_block    *decl_pos_block)
    2745             : /*
    2746             : Scan a function declarator, or an array declarator in an abstract declarator.
    2747             : Allocate and return in *new_type_ptr an appropriate function type.  The
    2748             : initial opening parenthesis has already been checked and passed over (which is
    2749             : unusual; that's necessary because of the syntactic strangeness of abstract
    2750             : declarators).  *state and di_flags describe the declaration being parsed.
    2751             : If func_info is NULL, then the function declarator is not for the top-level
    2752             : type or this is an abstract declarator (and therefore certain forms are
    2753             : disallowed); otherwise, extra information about the function declarator is
    2754             : returned in *func_info.  For member functions, parent_type is a pointer to the
    2755             : class (or struct or union) type of which it is a member; otherwise it is NULL.
    2756             : When parent_type is non-NULL, is_nonstatic_member distinguishes static from
    2757             : nonstatic member functions when the current scope is that of a class
    2758             : definition.  is_constructor, is_static_constructor, is_destructor, and
    2759             : is_finalizer indicate that previous processing determined that this is a
    2760             : constructor, a C++/CLI static constructor, a destructor, or a C++/CLI
    2761             : finalizer declaration, respectively.  If disallow_default_args is TRUE issue
    2762             : an error if a default argument expression is encountered.
    2763             : */

    2765     1164190 :   a_param_type_ptr        ptp;

    3292             :             /* Consider a case like the following:
    3293             :                  template<class ... Ts> struct S {
    3294             :                    template<class F> auto m(F f, Ts... p)->decltype(f(p...));
    3295             :                  };
    3296             :                During a real instantiation of S, any number of parameters p
    3297             :                may be created, each marked as a "pack element".  However, when
    3298             :                "p..." is rescanned in the return type, we'll need to know that
    3299             :                p was a parameter pack (to validate the ellipsis and set up
    3300             :                another context for expansion).  We therefore mark the first

    3757             :                A::A(A%);               // case 5
    3758             :                A::A(A%, T=x, A=y);     // case 6

    4075           0 : }  /* scan_lambda_declarator */
    4076             : 
    4077             : 
    4078        5805 : static void make_bound_expr_referenceable_from_file_scope(
    4079             :                                                         an_expr_node_ptr *expr,
    4080             :                                                         a_type_ptr       type,
    4081             :                                                         a_boolean        dep)
    4082             : /*
    4083             : Process an expression used as an array bound (may be NULL) so that it can
    4084             : be referred to by the given type entry.  Because types appear in file scope
    4085             : and file scope entries cannot refer to local scope entries, either copy the
    4086             : expression tree to the current memory region (assumed to be file scope upon
    4087             : entry) or create a local expr_node reference to it and mark the type entry
    4088             : accordingly.  If the expression tree was copied, the original expression
    4089             : pointer is updated to point to the copy; if a local expr_node reference was
    4090             : created, the original expression pointer is set to NULL.  dep is TRUE for
    4091             : the subexpressions of the ck_template_param for the template-dependent
    4092             : bound case, FALSE for the "expr" field of the constant itself.
    4093             : */
    4094             : {
    4095        5805 :   if (*expr != NULL) {
    4096        1136 :     if (expr_has_reference_to_routine_scope_variable(*expr)) {
    4097             :       /* The expression refers to a function-scope variable, so it can't be
    4098             :          referenced from file scope.  Create a local expr node reference to
    4099             :          it instead.  Use get_innermost_function_scope because we could be
    4100             :          in a local class here. */
    4101           4 :       a_scope_ptr function_scope = get_innermost_function_scope();
    4102           4 :       check_assertion(function_scope != NULL);
    4103           4 :       if (in_file_scope(*expr)) {
    4104             :         /* Even though there is a reference to a local variable somewhere
    4105             :            in the expression tree, the top-level node is in file-scope
    4106             :            memory.  Make a copy in the innermost function scope and use
    4107             :            that for the local expr node reference.  This copy is necessary
    4108             :            because of code in i_copy_constant_full that copies the expression
    4109             :            under tpck_expression constants unconditionally, which might mean
    4110             :            a copy from the function scope to the file scope there that would
    4111             :            have to be reversed here.  That's wrong, but for the reasons given
    4112             :            there it can't be fixed immediately, and this undoes most of the
    4113             :            damage.*/
    4114             : 
    4115           0 :         check_assertion(function_scope != NULL &&
    4116             :                         curr_il_region_number == file_scope_region_number);
    4117           0 :         switch_il_region(mem_region_for_routine(
    4118             :                                          function_scope->variant.routine.ptr));
    4119           0 :         *expr = copy_expr_tree(*expr, CE_NO_OPTIONS);
    4120           0 :         switch_il_region(file_scope_region_number);
    4121             :       }  /* if */
    4122           8 :       make_local_expr_node_ref(
    4123             :                       *expr,
    4124             :                       (dep ? (a_local_expr_node_ref_kind)lerk_dep_array_bound :
    4125             :                              (a_local_expr_node_ref_kind)lerk_array_bound),
    4126             :                       (char *)type, function_scope);
    4127           4 :       *expr = NULL;
    4128        1132 :     } else if (!in_file_scope(*expr)) {
    4129             :       /* Copy the expression to file-scope memory. */
    4130           1 :       *expr = copy_expr_tree(*expr, CE_NO_OPTIONS);
    4131             :     }  /* if */
    4132             :   }  /* if */
    4133        5805 : }  /* make_bound_expr_referenceable_from_file_scope */
    4134             : 
    4135             : 
    4136             : static a_boolean in_class_definition(void)
    4137             : /*
    4138             : Return TRUE if the current scope is a class scope or a function prototype
    4139             : scope in a class scope.
    4140             : */
    4141             : {
    4142             :   a_scope_stack_entry_ptr  ssep = &scope_stack_top();
    4143             : 
    4144             :   while (ssep->kind == (a_scope_kind)sck_func_prototype) ssep -= 1;
    4145             :   return ssep->kind == (a_scope_kind)sck_class_struct_union;
    4146             : }  /* in_class_definition */
    4147             : 
    4148             : 
    4149             : #if !UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    4150             : /*ARGSUSED*/  /* threads_dimension_allowed is only used in configurations
    4151             :                  supporting UPC extensions. */
    4152             : #endif /* !UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    4153        6706 : void array_declarator(a_decl_parse_state    *dps,
    4154             :                       a_type_ptr            *new_type_ptr,
    4155             :                       a_boolean             nonconstant_dimension_allowed,
    4156             :                       a_boolean             vla_allowed,
    4157             :                       a_boolean             vla_asterisk_allowed,
    4158             :                       a_boolean             threads_dimension_allowed,
    4159             :                       a_boolean             top_level_field_decl,
    4160             :                       a_boolean             top_level_param_decl,
    4161             :                       a_decl_pos_block_ptr  decl_pos_block)
    4162             : /*
    4163             : Scan an array declarator, or an array declarator in an abstract declarator.
    4164             : *dps describes the context of the call (e.g., if this declarator appears in an
    4165             : evaluated sizeof expression).  Allocate and return in *new_type_ptr an
    4166             : appropriate array type.  The initial opening bracket is the current token.
    4167             : In C++ the dimension may sometimes be a nonconstant expression (e.g., with a
    4168             : new type name); that case is indicated by nonconstant_dimension_allowed.
    4169             : When vla_enabled is TRUE, the dimension may be a nonconstant expression; and
    4170             : when vla_asterisk_allowed is TRUE, a VLA of unknown size can be indicated with
    4171             : the "[*]" syntax in a function prototype.  top_level_field_decl is TRUE to
    4172             : indicate that this is the declaration of a nonstatic data member of a class.
    4173             : top_level_param_decl is TRUE to indicate that this is a a top-level declarator
    4174             : in a function parameter declaration.  threads_dimension_allowed indicates
    4175             : whether the dimension expression can be a multiple of the special UPC THREADS
    4176             : constant.
    4177             : */
    4178             : {
    4179        6706 :   a_targ_size_t           num_of_elements = 0;
    4180        6706 :   a_constant_ptr          constant = local_constant();
    4181        6706 :   a_boolean               is_constant_bound = FALSE;
    4182        6706 :   a_boolean               err = FALSE;
    4183        6706 :   a_boolean               has_vla_asterisk = FALSE;
    4184        6706 :   a_boolean               template_dependent_bound = FALSE;
    4185        6706 :   a_source_position       start_pos, size_pos;
    4186        6706 :   an_expr_node_ptr        dim_expr = NULL;
    4187        6706 :   a_boolean               static_seen = FALSE;
    4188        6706 :   a_type_qualifier_set    qualifiers = TQ_NONE;
    4189             : #if UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    4190        6706 :   a_boolean               upc_threads_dimension = FALSE;
    4191             : #endif /* UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    4192             : 
    4193        6706 :   db_enter(3, "array_declarator");
    4194        6706 :   copy_source_position(pos_curr_token, start_pos);
    4195             :   /* Pass over the initial left bracket. */
    4196        6706 :   (void)get_token();
    4197        6706 :   add_stop_token(tok_rbracket);
    4198        6706 :   if (c99_mode && top_level_param_decl && curr_token == tok_static) {
    4199             :     /* In C99, "static" in an array declarator in a parameter declaration
    4200             :        indicates that the actual argument must have at least as many elements
    4201             :        as the declared size of the array. */
    4202           0 :     static_seen = TRUE;
    4203           0 :     (void)get_token();
    4204        6706 :   } else if (!C_mode() && (decl_scope_level == NO_SCOPE_DEPTH ||
    4205        1164 :                            scope_stack[decl_scope_level].kind ==
    4206             :                                           (a_scope_kind)sck_func_prototype)) {
    4207             :     /* In non-C modes, VLAs are never allowed in function prototypes. */
    4208         232 :     vla_allowed = vla_asterisk_allowed = FALSE;
    4209             :   }  /* if */
    4210             :   /* In some modes, "restrict" is allowed inside the brackets:
    4211             :        int x[restrict 5]
    4212             :      or
    4213             :        int y[restrict]
    4214             :      This is allowed only for formal parameter declarations, and
    4215             :      indicates that the pointer type to which the array type decays
    4216             :      is restrict-qualified (e.g., "restrict pointer to int" in
    4217             :      the first example above.  In C99, cv-qualifiers are also allowed

    4220           0 :     a_source_position     qualifier_pos;

    4224             :                                          (a_upc_block_size *)NULL);
