    4478             :             /* Do not copy the backing expression from the bound constant
    4479             :                if it results from invoking a lambda expression, as the
    4480             :                lambda may have references to local variables. */
    4481             :           } else {
    4482             :             /* Preserve the bound expression, which will not have been
    4483             :                copied if it refers to local variables, and ensure that it
    4484             :                can be referenced from the file-scope type entry.  Note that
    4485             :                il_constant will be unshared in this case because of the
    4486             :                non-NULL backing expression in the source constant, even
    4487             :                though the backing expression was cleared in il_constant. */
    4488        5789 :             il_constant->expr = constant->expr;
    4489        5789 :             make_bound_expr_referenceable_from_file_scope(&il_constant->expr,
    4490             :                                                           *new_type_ptr,
    4491             :                                                           /*dep=*/FALSE);
    4492             :           }  /* if */
    4493        5789 :           (*new_type_ptr)->variant.array.bound_constant = il_constant;
    4494             :         }  /* if */
    4495        6400 :         (*new_type_ptr)->variant.array.variant.number_of_elements =
    4496             :                                                               num_of_elements;
    4497        6400 :         if (((gnu_mode && is_constant_bound) ||
    4498        6400 :              (gpp_mode && top_level_field_decl)) &&
    4499             :              num_of_elements == 0) {
    4500             :           /* Record the fact that we saw a GNU C zero-length array.  GNU C++
    4501             :              compilers treat flexible array members ([]) as zero-length arrays
    4502             :              ([0]). */
    4503           0 :           (*new_type_ptr)->variant.array.bound_is_zero = TRUE;
    4504           0 :           if (is_constant_bound) {
    4505           0 :             report_gnu_extension_if_needed(
    4506        6636 :                              &size_pos, ec_zero_length_array_is_gnu_extension);
    4507             :           }  /* if */
    4508             :         }  /* if */
    4509             :       }  /* if */
    4510        6636 :       switch_back_to_original_region(region_to_switch_back_to);
    4511             :     }  /* if */
    4512        6706 :     if (gnu_mode && !c99_mode && (*new_type_ptr)->variant.array.is_vla) {
    4513           1 :       report_gnu_extension_if_needed(&size_pos, ec_vla_is_nonstandard);
    4514             :     }  /* if */
    4515             : #if UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    4516             :     /* Record whether the dimension is a multiple of THREADS. */
    4517        6706 :     (*new_type_ptr)->variant.array.is_threads_dimension =
    4518             :                                                         upc_threads_dimension;
    4519             : #endif /* UPC_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    4520             :     /* The size of the array (in bytes) is updated in 
    4521             :        add_to_derived_type_list. */
    4522             :   }  /* if */
    4523             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL
    4524        6706 :   if (decl_pos_block != NULL) {
    4525        6486 :     decl_pos_block->declarator_range.end = end_pos_curr_token;
    4526             :   }  /* if */
    4527        6706 :   curr_construct_end_position = end_pos_curr_token;
    4528             : #endif /* EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */
    4529             :   /* Check for closing right bracket. */
    4530        6706 :   (void)required_token(tok_rbracket, ec_exp_rbracket);
    4531        6706 :   remove_stop_token(tok_rbracket);
    4532        6706 :   copy_source_position(start_pos, error_position);
    4533        6706 :   scan_declarator_attributes(dps, new_type_ptr);
    4534        6706 :   release_local_constant(&constant);
    4535        6706 :   db_exit();
    4536        6706 : }  /* array_declarator */
    4537             : 
    4538             : 
    4539             : /*
    4540             : A structure to track various modifications that might have been applied to a
    4541             : pointer declarator.  This includes not only the standard const/volatile
    4542             : qualifiers, but also a variety of Microsoft extensions (e.g., __ptr64/__ptr32
    4543             : and calling conventions).
    4544             : */
    4545             : typedef struct a_pointer_modifier_state {
    4546             :   a_type_qualifier_set
    4547             :                 qualifiers;
    4548             :                         /* Standard and nonstandard qualifiers. */
    4549             :   a_source_position
    4550             :                 qualifiers_pos;
    4551             :                         /* The position of the first qualifier seen. */
    4552             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    4553             :   a_call_conv_descr
    4554             :                 cc_descr;
    4555             :                         /* Microsoft calling convention. */
    4556             :   a_variable_ptr
    4557             :                 based_var;
    4558             :                         /* The variable specified by a __based modifier (if
    4559             :                            any). */
    4560             :   a_source_position
    4561             :                 based_pos;
    4562             :                         /* The source position of the __based modifier (if
    4563             :                            any). */
    4564             :   a_boolean
    4565             :                 microsoft_w64;
    4566             :                         /* TRUE if the __w64 token was seen. */
    4567             :   a_source_position
    4568             :                 microsoft_w64_pos;
    4569             :                         /* The source position of the __w64 token (if any). */
    4570             :   a_pointer_modifier_set
    4571             :                 modifiers;
    4572             :                         /* A bit set describing the presence of certain
    4573             :                            additional modifiers (like __ptr32). */
    4574             :                            
    4575             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    4576             : } a_pointer_modifier_state;
    4577             : 
    4578             : 
    4579     3428380 : static void clear_pointer_modifier_state(a_pointer_modifier_state  *ptr_mods)
    4580             : /*
    4581             : Clear the pointer modifiers structure (except for some position information
    4582             : that isn't accessed unless the associated flag has been set).
    4583             : */
    4584             : {
    4585     3428380 :   ptr_mods->qualifiers = TQ_NONE;
    4586     3428380 :   ptr_mods->qualifiers_pos = null_source_position;
    4587             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    4588             :   clear_call_conv_descr(&ptr_mods->cc_descr);
    4589             :   ptr_mods->based_var = NULL;
    4590             :   ptr_mods->microsoft_w64 = FALSE;
    4591             :   ptr_mods->modifiers = PM_NONE;
    4592             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    4593     3428380 : }  /* clear_pointer_modifier_state */
    4594             : 
    4595             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    4596             : 
    4597             : static void scan_microsoft_calling_convention(a_calling_convention *call_conv)
    4598             : /*
    4599             : Scan a list of Microsoft calling conventions (__cdecl, __fastcall, __stdcall,
    4600             : __thiscall, __clrcall).  Only one calling convention may be specified, but the
    4601             : same specifier may appear more than once.  It can be assumed that
    4602             : is_microsoft_calling_convention is TRUE on entry.  *call_conv on entry
    4603             : has any calling convention previously scanned, or is cc_default if there
    4604             : was no previous calling convention.  On exit it is set to the calling
    4605             : convention scanned on this call.
    4606             : */
    4607             : {
    4608             :   set_err_pos_to_curr_token();
    4609             :   do {
    4610             :     a_calling_convention new_call_conv = (a_calling_convention)cc_default;
    4611             :     switch (curr_token) {
    4612             :       case tok_cdecl:
    4613             :         new_call_conv = (a_calling_convention)cc_cdecl;
    4614             :         break;
    4615             :       case tok_vectorcall:
    4616             :         new_call_conv = (a_calling_convention)cc_vectorcall;
    4617             :         break;
    4618             :       case tok_fastcall:
    4619             :         new_call_conv = (a_calling_convention)cc_fastcall;
    4620             :         break;
    4621             :       case tok_stdcall:
    4622             :         new_call_conv = (a_calling_convention)cc_stdcall;
    4623             :         break;
    4624             :       case tok_thiscall:
    4625             :         new_call_conv = (a_calling_convention)cc_thiscall;
    4626             :         break;
    4627             :       case tok_clrcall:
    4628             :         if (cppcli_enabled) {
    4629             :           new_call_conv = (a_calling_convention)cc_clrcall;
    4630             :         } else {
    4631             :           pos_error(ec_clrcall_requires_cppcli, &error_position);
    4632             :           goto skip_token;
    4633             :         }  /* if */
    4634             :         break;
    4635             :       default: unexpected_condition();
    4636             :     }  /* switch */
    4637             :     if (*call_conv != (a_calling_convention)cc_default) {
    4638             :       /* A calling convention was specified. */
    4639             :       if (*call_conv != new_call_conv) {
    4640             :         /* The new calling convention does not agree with the old one. */
    4641             :         pos_error(ec_conflicting_calling_conventions, &error_position);
    4642             :       } else {
    4643             :         /* The new and old calling conventions are the same. */
    4644             :         pos_warning(ec_dupl_calling_convention, &error_position);
    4645             :       }  /* if */
    4646             :     }  /* if */
    4647             :     *call_conv = new_call_conv;
    4648             : skip_token:
    4649             :     (void)get_token();
    4650             :   } while (is_microsoft_calling_convention(curr_token));
    4651             : }  /* scan_microsoft_calling_convention */
    4652             : 
    4653             : 
    4654             : static
    4655             : void update_calling_convention(a_type_ptr             *type,
    4656             :                                a_call_conv_descr_ptr  p_calling_convention,
    4657             :                                a_decl_parse_state     *dps,
    4658             :                                a_source_position      *decl_pos)
    4659             : /*
    4660             : Determine the validity of the given calling convention specified for the
    4661             : given type in a declaration described by *dps.  If appropriate, issue a
    4662             : diagnostic at the given position.
    4663             : */
    4664             : {
    4665             :   a_calling_convention           calling_convention;
    4666             :   a_boolean                      discard = FALSE;
    4667             :   an_error_severity              discard_sev = (an_error_severity)es_remark;
    4668             :   a_routine_type_supplement_ptr  rtsp;
    4669             : 
    4670             :   calling_convention = p_calling_convention->call_conv;
    4671             :   if (*type == NULL) {
    4672             :     /* Null type -- the calling convention will be discarded. */
    4673             :     discard = TRUE;
    4674             :   } else if (calling_convention != (a_calling_convention)cc_default) {
    4675             :     if (!is_function_type(*type)) {
    4676             :       /* A calling convention on a non-function type is ignored. */
    4677             :       pos_remark(ec_calling_convention_ignored_for_type, decl_pos);
    4678             :     } else {
    4679             :       /* A calling convention applied to a function type. */
    4680             :       if (is_qualified_type(*type)) {
    4681             :         /* The type involves qualifiers on top of a routine type.  This is an
    4682             :            unusual situation that can only occur when a type qualifier is
    4683             :            applied to a typedef that points to a routine type.  If a calling
    4684             :            convention were allowed to be declared on top of that, it would
    4685             :            cause the underlying routine type to be modified; but that would
    4686             :            affect the meaning of the typedef that points to it.  Another
    4687             :            approach would be to copy the routine type, add the calling
    4688             :            convention to the copy, and then reapply the qualifier directly to
    4689             :            the copy, but this has implementation difficulties: among other
    4690             :            things, without a typedef in the resulting type tree the type can't
    4691             :            be represented outside the IL (e.g., in diagnostics).  Here's an
    4692             :            example of what is disallowed:
    4693             :              typedef void F(int);
    4694             :              typedef const F CF;
    4695             :              extern CF __stdcall f;     // __stdcall is not allowed here
    4696             :            This should be a very rarely encountered limitation, since type
    4697             :            qualifiers are uncommon on routine types to begin with. */
    4698             :         /* An error is issued, since to just to ignore the declaration (even
    4699             :            with a warning) could give the user a false impression. */
    4700             :         pos_error(ec_calling_convention_not_allowed, decl_pos);
    4701             :       } else {
    4702             :         a_type_ptr  tp = *type;
    4703             :         a_boolean   any_typedefs = FALSE;
    4704             : 
    4705             :         /* Skip past any typerefs.  See if any of them are typedefs. */
    4706             :         while (tp->kind == (a_type_kind)tk_typeref) {
    4707             :           any_typedefs |= (int)(typeref_is_typedef(tp));
    4708             :           tp = tp->variant.typeref.type;
    4709             :         }  /* while */
    4710             :         check_assertion(tp->kind == (a_type_kind)tk_routine);
    4711             :         rtsp = tp->variant.routine.extra_info;
    4712             :         if (rtsp->has_ellipsis) {
    4713             :           /* Calling convention for functions with variable argument lists
    4714             :              is always __cdecl.  Whether or not __cdecl was explicitly
    4715             :              specified, add it to the type. */
    4716             :           rtsp->calling_convention = (a_calling_convention)cc_cdecl;
    4717             :           rtsp->explicit_calling_convention = TRUE;
    4718             :           if (calling_convention != (a_calling_convention)cc_cdecl) {
    4719             :             /* For __thiscall or __clrcall, an error should be issued.  The
    4720             :                other cases only elicit a remark (issued below). */
    4721             :             if (calling_convention == (a_calling_convention)cc_thiscall) {
    4722             :               pos_error(ec_vararg_thiscall, &error_position);
    4723             :             } else if (calling_convention ==
    4724             :                                            (a_calling_convention)cc_clrcall) {
    4725             :               pos_error(ec_vararg_clrcall, &error_position);
    4726             :             } else {
    4727             :               discard = TRUE;
    4728             :             }  /* if */
    4729             :           }  /* if */
    4730             :         } else if (rtsp->calling_convention ==
    4731             :                                            (a_calling_convention)cc_clrcall &&
    4732             :                    calling_convention != (a_calling_convention)cc_clrcall &&
    4733             :                    !dps->is_explicit_instantiation) {
    4734             :           /* A calling convention of __clrcall cannot be "overridden" by a
    4735             :              different convention.  (For explicit instantiations, do not
    4736             :              discard the explicit calling convention: It affects deduction
    4737             :              and will likely trigger an error later on because the template
    4738             :              presumably doesn't have the same convention.) */
    4739             :           discard = TRUE;
    4740             :           discard_sev = (an_error_severity)es_warning;
    4741             :         } else if ((rtsp->assoc_routine_is_ctor ||
    4742             :                     rtsp->assoc_routine_is_dtor) &&
    4743             :                    calling_convention != (a_calling_convention)cc_thiscall &&
    4744             :                    calling_convention != (a_calling_convention)cc_clrcall) {
    4745             :           /* Microsoft compilers ignore __cdecl and __fastcall specifiers on
    4746             :              constructors with a warning.  They silently also ignore __stdcall.
    4747             :              All these cases are treated as __thiscall instead.  We discard all
    4748             :              calling conventions on constructors and destructors with a
    4749             :              warning, except __thiscall and __clrcall. */
    4750             :           discard = TRUE;
    4751             :           discard_sev = (an_error_severity)es_warning;
    4752             :         } else if (rtsp->calling_convention != calling_convention) {
    4753             :           /* The underlying routine type needs to be updated. */
    4754             :           if (any_typedefs) {
    4755             :             /* Copy the routine type, since it's about to be modified and we
    4756             :                don't want to change the meaning of the typedef.  But that
    4757             :                means *type has to be adjusted. */
    4758             :             tp = copy_routine_type_with_param_types(tp,
    4759             :                                                    /*copy_default_args=*/TRUE);
    4760             :             *type = tp;
    4761             :             rtsp = tp->variant.routine.extra_info;
    4762             :           }  /* if */
    4763             :           rtsp->calling_convention = calling_convention;
    4764             :           rtsp->explicit_calling_convention = TRUE;
    4765             :         }  /* if */
    4766             :       }  /* if */
    4767             :     }  /* if */
    4768             :   }  /* if */
    4769             :   if (discard) {
    4770             :     /* Issue a diagnostic (remark or warning) indicating that the calling
    4771             :        convention has no effect. */
    4772             :     pos_diagnostic(discard_sev, ec_calling_convention_ignored,
    4773             :                    &p_calling_convention->position);
    4774             :   }  /* if */
    4775             :   /* Whether or not we were able to apply the calling convention,
    4776             :      reset it so that the caller does not attempt to reuse it later. */
    4777             :   clear_call_conv_descr(p_calling_convention);
    4778             : }  /* update_calling_convention */
    4779             : 
    4780             : 
    4781             : static a_variable_ptr scan_based_modifier(void)
    4782             : /*
    4783             : Scan the Microsoft __based modifier.  The syntax is
    4784             : 
    4785             :         __based(identifier)
    4786             : 
    4787             : The identifier must name a variable with pointer type.  Return a
    4788             : pointer to the variable.  If the identifier is undefined, or
    4789             : is not a variable with pointer type, return NULL.
    4790             : */
    4791             : {
    4792             :   a_variable_ptr        var = NULL;
    4793             : 
    4794             :   check_assertion(curr_token == tok_based);
    4795             :   /* Bypass the __based token. */
    4796             :   (void)get_token();
    4797             :   if (required_token(tok_lparen, ec_exp_lparen)) {
    4798             :     add_stop_token(tok_rparen);
    4799             :     if (!is_generalized_identifier_start(GID_NO_OPTIONS)) {
    4800             :       syntax_error(ec_exp_identifier);
    4801             :       /* Flush tokens to the right paren. */
    4802             :       flush_tokens();
    4803             :     } else {
    4804             :       /* Call an expression routine to scan the identifier.  The routine
    4805             :          will return NULL if an error occurred while scanning the variable. */
    4806             :       var = based_variable();
    4807             :     }  /* if */
    4808             :     remove_stop_token(tok_rparen);
    4809             :     /* Bypass the closing parenthesis. */
    4810             :     (void)required_token(tok_rparen, ec_exp_rparen);
    4811             :   }  /* if */
    4812             :   return var;
    4813             : }  /* scan_based_modifier */
    4814             : 
    4815             : 
    4816             : static void issue_invalid_based_error(a_source_position *pos)
    4817             : /*
    4818             : Issue an error that a __based modifier is not allowed in the
    4819             : indicated position.
    4820             : */
    4821             : {
    4822             :   pos_error(ec_based_not_allowed_here, pos);
    4823             : }  /* issue_invalid_based_error */
    4824             : 
    4825             : /*
    4826             : Macro that tests whether a based symbol is present and, if so, issues
    4827             : an error and resets the symbol.  This macro expands to nothing when
    4828             : Microsoft extensions are not allowed.
    4829             : */
    4830             : #define based_not_allowed_here(var, pos)                              \
    4831             :   { if ((var) != NULL) issue_invalid_based_error(&pos); var = NULL; }
    4832             : 
    4833             : #else  /* !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    4834             : 
    4835             : /*
    4836             : Expands to nothing when Microsoft extensions are not being used.
    4837             : */
    4838             : #define based_not_allowed_here(var, pos)  /* Nothing */
    4839             : 
    4840             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    4841             : 
    4842             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED
    4843             : 
    4844             : #if !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    4845             : /*ARGSUSED*/ /* <-- because when MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED is FALSE,
    4846             :                     plain_ptr_seen and ptr_to_member_seen are not used. */
    4847             : #endif /* !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    4848             : static void collect_pointer_declarator_extended_qualifiers(
    4849             :                                   a_boolean                 plain_ptr_seen,
    4850             :                                   a_boolean                 ptr_to_member_seen,
    4851             :                                   a_pointer_modifier_state  *ptr_mods,
    4852             :                                   a_decl_pos_block_ptr      decl_pos_block)
    4853             : /*
    4854             : Collect a set of pointer declarator qualifiers provided as an extension
    4855             : (e.g., for Microsoft compatibility).  Aside from the standard const/volatile,
    4856             : support for near and far may be enabled (e.g., in Microsoft 16-bit mode),
    4857             : and Microsoft mode also allows other modifiers, notably __based and calling
    4858             : conventions like __cdecl.  Scan all of those, and return information about what
    4859             : was scanned in *ptr_mods (the caller need not initialize this structure).
    4860             : It's permissible for the input to contain no qualifiers. If Microsoft extended
    4861             : decl specifiers, introduced by __declspec, are encountered, they are
    4862             : scanned and thrown away with a warning.  plain_ptr_seen is TRUE when scanning
    4863             : extended qualifiers following a asterisk ("*") indicating a plain pointer.
    4864             : ptr_to_member_seen is TRUE when scanning extended qualifiers following a
    4865             : pointer-to-member operator (of the form X::* for some class type X).
    4866             : Additional position information is recorded in *decl_pos_block.
    4867             : */
    4868             : {
    4869             :   a_type_qualifier_set new_qualifiers, duplicates;
    4870             : 
    4871             :   clear_pointer_modifier_state(ptr_mods);
    4872             :   for (;;) {
    4873             :     if (is_type_qualifier() or_is_near_or_far()) {
    4874             :       /* Normal qualifiers like const, and declarator-only qualifiers like
    4875             :          near. */
    4876             :       ptr_mods->qualifiers_pos = pos_curr_token;
    4877             :       new_qualifiers = collect_type_qualifiers(decl_pos_block,
    4878             :                                                (a_upc_block_size *)NULL);
    4879             :       duplicates = (new_qualifiers & ptr_mods->qualifiers);
    4880             : #if NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED
    4881             :       if (near_and_far_enabled()) {
    4882             :         if ((new_qualifiers & TQ_NEAR) && (ptr_mods->qualifiers & TQ_FAR )) {
    4883             :           /* Incompatible near and far specifications. */
    4884             :           pos_error(ec_mem_attrib_incompatible, &error_position);
    4885             :           new_qualifiers &= ~TQ_NEAR;
    4886             :           duplicates &= ~TQ_NEAR;
    4887             :         }  /* if */
    4888             :         if ((new_qualifiers & TQ_FAR ) && (ptr_mods->qualifiers & TQ_NEAR)) {
    4889             :           /* Incompatible near and far specifications. */
    4890             :           pos_error(ec_mem_attrib_incompatible, &error_position);
    4891             :           new_qualifiers &= ~TQ_FAR;
    4892             :           duplicates &= ~TQ_FAR;
    4893             :         }  /* if */
    4894             :         /* Check for repetition of "near" or "far".  The Microsoft compiler
    4895             :            gives only a warning for these cases, so we do too. */
    4896             :         if (duplicates & (TQ_NEAR | TQ_FAR)) {
    4897             :           pos_warning(ec_dupl_mem_attrib, &error_position);
    4898             :           duplicates &= ~(TQ_NEAR | TQ_FAR);
    4899             :         }  /* if */
    4900             :       }  /* if */
    4901             : #endif /* NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED */
    4902             :       /* Check for duplicates other than "near" and "far". */
    4903             :       if (duplicates != TQ_NONE) {
    4904             :         /* The Microsoft compiler gives only a warning for duplicates, so
    4905             :            we do too. */
    4906             :         pos_warning(ec_dupl_type_qualifier, &error_position);
    4907             :       }  /* if */
    4908             :       ptr_mods->qualifiers |= new_qualifiers;
    4909             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    4910             :     } else if (ms_extensions) {
    4911             :       if (is_microsoft_calling_convention(curr_token)) {
    4912             :         /* Calling conventions like __cdecl. */
    4913             :         ptr_mods->cc_descr.position = pos_curr_token;
    4914             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL
    4915             :         if (decl_pos_block != NULL) {
    4916             :           decl_pos_block->declarator_range.end = end_pos_curr_token;
    4917             :         }  /* if */
    4918             :         curr_construct_end_position = end_pos_curr_token;
    4919             : #endif /* EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */
    4920             :         scan_microsoft_calling_convention(&ptr_mods->cc_descr.call_conv);
    4921             :       } else if (curr_token == tok_based) {
    4922             :         /* __based. */
    4923             :         if (ptr_mods->based_var != NULL) {
    4924             :           /* __based appears more than once. */
    4925             :           pos_error(ec_dupl_type_qualifier, &error_position);
    4926             :         }  /* if */
    4927             :         ptr_mods->based_pos = pos_curr_token;
    4928             :         ptr_mods->based_var = scan_based_modifier();
    4929             :       } else if (curr_token == tok_declspec) {
    4930             :         /* Scan the decl-modifiers.  The Microsoft compiler appears to accept
    4931             :            and ignore __declspec declarations that appear during declarator
    4932             :            processing -- there is no evidence that the decl-modifiers are ever
    4933             :            actually applied to the function or variable being declared. */
    4934             :         scan_and_discard_extended_decl_modifiers();
    4935             :       } else if (curr_token == tok_mutable) {
    4936             :         /* The Microsoft compiler appears to accept and ignore "mutable"
    4937             :            during declarator processing.  Issue a warning and continue. */
    4938             :         pos_warning(ec_mutable_not_allowed, &error_position);
    4939             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL
    4940             :         if (decl_pos_block != NULL) {
    4941             :           decl_pos_block->declarator_range.end = end_pos_curr_token;
    4942             :         }  /* if */
    4943             :         curr_construct_end_position = end_pos_curr_token;
    4944             : #endif /* EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */
    4945             :         (void)get_token();
    4946             :       } else if (curr_token == tok_microsoft_w64) {
    4947             :         /* Microsoft compilers accept the __w64 keyword on pointer
    4948             :            declarators. */

    4950             :           ptr_mods->microsoft_w64 = TRUE;
    4951             :           ptr_mods->microsoft_w64_pos = pos_curr_token;
    4952             :         } else {
    4953             :           /* The "__w64" token was not expected. */
    4954             :           pos_error(ec_invalid_type_for_w64, &error_position);
    4955             :         }  /* if */
    4956             :         (void)get_token();
    4957             :       } else if (curr_token == tok_microsoft_ptr32) {
    4958             :         if (!plain_ptr_seen && !ptr_to_member_seen) {
    4959             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_width_must_follow_star, &error_position);
    4960             :         } else if ((ptr_mods->modifiers & PM_PTR64) != 0) {
    4961             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_width_conflict, &error_position);
    4962             :         } else if ((ptr_mods->modifiers & PM_PTR32) != 0) {
    4963             :           pos_warning(ec_dupl_type_qualifier, &error_position);
    4964             :         } else {
    4965             :           ptr_mods->modifiers |= PM_PTR32;
    4966             :         }  /* if */
    4967             :         (void)get_token();
    4968             :       } else if (curr_token == tok_microsoft_ptr64) {
    4969             :         if (!plain_ptr_seen && !ptr_to_member_seen) {
    4970             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_width_must_follow_star, &error_position);
    4971             :         } else if ((ptr_mods->modifiers & PM_PTR32) != 0) {
    4972             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_width_conflict, &error_position);
    4973             :         } else if ((ptr_mods->modifiers & PM_PTR64) != 0) {
    4974             :           pos_warning(ec_dupl_type_qualifier, &error_position);
    4975             :         } else {
    4976             :           ptr_mods->modifiers |= PM_PTR64;
    4977             :         }  /* if */
    4978             :         (void)get_token();
    4979             :       } else if (curr_token == tok_microsoft_sptr) {
    4980             :         if (ptr_to_member_seen) {
    4981             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_signedness_on_ptr_to_member,
    4982             :                     &error_position);
    4983             :         } else if (!plain_ptr_seen) {
    4984             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_signedness_must_follow_star,
    4985             :                     &error_position);
    4986             :         } else if ((ptr_mods->modifiers & PM_UPTR) != 0) {
    4987             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_signedness_conflict, &error_position);
    4988             :         } else if ((ptr_mods->modifiers & PM_SPTR) != 0) {
    4989             :           pos_warning(ec_dupl_type_qualifier, &error_position);
    4990             :         } else {
    4991             :           ptr_mods->modifiers |= PM_SPTR;
    4992             :         }  /* if */
    4993             :         (void)get_token();
    4994             :       } else if (curr_token == tok_microsoft_uptr) {
    4995             :         if (ptr_to_member_seen) {
    4996             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_signedness_on_ptr_to_member,
    4997             :                     &error_position);
    4998             :         } else if (!plain_ptr_seen) {
    4999             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_signedness_must_follow_star,
    5000             :                     &error_position);
    5001             :         } else if ((ptr_mods->modifiers & PM_SPTR) != 0) {
    5002             :           pos_error(ec_microsoft_ptr_signedness_conflict, &error_position);
    5003             :         } else if ((ptr_mods->modifiers & PM_UPTR) != 0) {
    5004             :           pos_warning(ec_dupl_type_qualifier, &error_position);
    5005             :         } else {
    5006             :           ptr_mods->modifiers |= PM_UPTR;
    5007             :         }  /* if */
    5008             :         (void)get_token();
    5009             :       } else {
    5010             :         /* Something else; exit the loop. */
    5011             :         break;
    5012             :       }  /* if */
    5013             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5014             :     } else {
    5015             :       break;
    5016             :     }  /* if */
    5017             :   }  /* for */
    5018             : }  /* collect_pointer_declarator_extended_qualifiers */
    5019             : 
    5020             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED */
    5021             : #if NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED
    5022             : 
    5023             : static void check_for_addition_of_incompatible_qualifiers(
    5024             :                                               a_type_ptr           type,
    5025             :                                               a_type_qualifier_set *qualifiers,
    5026             :                                               a_source_position    *pos)
    5027             : /*
    5028             : The memory attribute qualifiers in the set *qualifiers are about to be added
    5029             : to the indicated type.  If there is some conflict between the new qualifiers
    5030             : and the existing ones (explicit and implied), issue an error (at position
    5031             : *pos) and remove the incompatible qualifiers from *qualifiers.
    5032             : */
    5033             : {
    5034             :   a_type_qualifier_set new_qualifiers = *qualifiers;
    5035             : 
    5036             :   if (new_qualifiers & (TQ_NEAR | TQ_FAR)) {
    5037             :     /* Adding a memory attribute.  See if there is a conflicting one
    5038             :        already. */

    5045             :       *qualifiers = new_qualifiers;

    5047             :   }  /* if */
    5048             : }  /* check_for_addition_of_incompatible_qualifiers */
    5049             : 
    5050             : #endif /* NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED */
    5051             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    5052             : 
    5053             : static void apply_microsoft_ptr_modifiers(
    5054             :                                           a_type_ptr                *type,
    5055             :                                           a_pointer_modifier_state  *ptr_mods)
    5056             : /*
    5057             : Replace *type by a similar type with added microsoft-specific modifiers as
    5058             : described by *ptr_mods (including __ptr32/__ptr64/__sptr/__uptr modifiers,
    5059             : __w64 annotation, and __based variable specifiers).  The given type must be a
    5060             : (possibly qualified) pointer or pointer-to-member type.
    5061             : */
    5062             : {
    5063             :   a_type_qualifier_set  qualifiers = get_type_qualifiers(*type);
    5064             :   a_type_ptr            plain_type = skip_typerefs(*type), copy;
    5065             :   a_boolean             copy_needed = ptr_mods->microsoft_w64 ||
    5066             :                                       ptr_mods->based_var != NULL;
    5067             : 
    5068             :   if (ptr_mods->modifiers != PM_NONE || copy_needed) {
    5069             :     /* Create a modified copy of the unqualified type and then reapply the
    5070             :        qualifiers (if any). */
    5071             :     if (plain_type->kind == (a_type_kind)tk_pointer) {
    5072             :       /* A plain pointer type: Modify it according to *ptr_mods.  If __w64 or
    5073             :          __based were applied, disable reusing an entry from the "based" list
    5074             :          by calling make_pointer_type_full with a NULL underlying type. */
    5075             :       a_type_ptr  tpt = copy_needed ? NULL : plain_type->variant.pointer.type;
    5076             :       copy = make_pointer_type_full(tpt, ptr_mods->modifiers);
    5077             :       copy->variant.pointer.type = plain_type->variant.pointer.type;
    5078             :       copy->has_microsoft_w64_specifier = ptr_mods->microsoft_w64;
    5079             :       copy->variant.pointer.base_variable = ptr_mods->based_var;
    5080             :       /* Mark the base variable as consumed. */
    5081             :       ptr_mods->based_var = NULL;
    5082             :     } else {
    5083             :       check_assertion(plain_type->kind == (a_type_kind)tk_ptr_to_member);
    5084             :       if (pm_member_type(plain_type) == NULL) {
    5085             :         /* The type is under construction.  We can therefore just modify it
    5086             :            "in place". */
    5087             :         copy = plain_type;
    5088             :         copy->variant.ptr_to_member.modifiers = ptr_mods->modifiers;
    5089             :       } else {
    5090             :         copy = ptr_to_member_type_full(pm_member_type(plain_type),
    5091             :                                        pm_class_type(plain_type),
    5092             :                                        ptr_mods->modifiers);
    5093             :       }  /* if */
    5094             :       /* Issue an error if this was preceded by __based. */
    5095             :       based_not_allowed_here(ptr_mods->based_var, ptr_mods->based_pos);
    5096             :       if (ptr_mods->microsoft_w64) {
    5097             :         pos_error(ec_invalid_type_for_w64, &ptr_mods->microsoft_w64_pos);
    5098             :       }  /* if */
    5099             :     }  /* if */
    5100             :     *type = make_qualified_type(copy, qualifiers);
    5101             :   }  /* if */
    5102             : }  /* apply_microsoft_ptr_modifiers */
    5103             : 
    5104             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5105             : 
    5106             : #if !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    5107             : /*ARGSUSED*/ /* <-- left_calling_convention and unbound_calling_convention
    5108             :                     are only used when Microsoft extensions are allowed.
    5109             :                     Moreover, left_qualifiers and unbound_qualifiers are used
    5110             :                     only if either Microsoft extensions or near/far are
    5111             :                     allowed. */
    5112             : #endif /* !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5113     3428380 : a_type_ptr pointer_declarator(
    5114             :                       a_type_ptr            specifiers_type,
    5115             :                       a_decl_parse_state    *state,
    5116             :                       a_boolean             reference_allowed,
    5117             :                       a_call_conv_descr_ptr left_calling_convention,
    5118             :                       a_call_conv_descr_ptr unbound_calling_convention,
    5119             :                       a_type_qualifier_set  *left_qualifiers,
    5120             :                       a_type_qualifier_set  *unbound_qualifiers,
    5121             :                       a_boolean             *ptr_to_member_scanned,
    5122             :                       a_decl_pos_block_ptr  decl_pos_block)
    5123             : /*
    5124             : Scan the pointer component of a declarator.  This is "*", "&", "&&", or "C::*"
    5125             : (where C is a class type) optionally followed by "const" and/or "volatile".
    5126             : "&" (lvalue reference) and "C::*" (pointer-to-member) are C++ features; "&&"
    5127             : is a C++11 extension to declare "rvalue references".  In C++/CLI mode the
    5128             : declarator operators "^" (handle) and "%" (tracking reference) are also
    5129             : possible.
    5130             : 
    5131             : This routine actually scans a sequence of pointer declarators.
    5132             : The pointer type modifiers are placed on top of the type passed in as
    5133             : specifiers_type, and a pointer to the complete type is returned.
    5134             : specifiers_type is NULL for a nested declarator (one enclosed in
    5135             : parentheses); in that case the pointer type modifiers are built up
    5136             : but nothing is attached to the bottom-most modifier.  In either case,
    5137             : ptr_to_member_scanned is set to TRUE if a pointer-to-member declarator
    5138             : was scanned, and to FALSE otherwise.
    5139             : 
    5140             : *state describes some state information about the current declaration.
    5141             : reference_allowed is FALSE if reference declarators ("&" and "&&") should be
    5142             : disallowed (e.g., in a new-expression).
    5143             : 
    5144             : In Microsoft mode, the Microsoft __cdecl, __stdcall, __fastcall, __thiscall,
    5145             : and __clrcall are recognized as calling conventions.  The handling of calling
    5146             : conventions is intended to match the behavior of the Microsoft 32-bit C/C++
    5147             : compiler.  Calling conventions are allowed on function types and pointer to
    5148             : function types.  They are permitted on object declarations, but have no
    5149             : meaning.  They are not allowed on pointers to objects or on references.
    5150             : 
    5151             : left_calling_convention and unbound_calling_convention are pointers
    5152             : to calling conventions.  The values of these calling conventions
    5153             : are returned by this routine.  If the pointer declarator looks like
    5154             : 
    5155             :         __cdecl * __cdecl * __cdecl
    5156             : 
    5157             : the first calling convention is returned in *left_calling_convention
    5158             : (but only if specifiers_type is NULL; otherwise, it is applied directly
    5159             : to the specifiers type); the middle one is discarded (by applying it
    5160             : to the pointer type); and the last one (not followed by a pointer
    5161             : operator) is returned in *unbound_calling_convention.  If
    5162             : unbound_calling_convention is NULL, an unbound calling convention
    5163             : is just thrown away.
    5164             : 
    5165             : Also in Microsoft mode, type qualifiers can appear at the beginning of
    5166             : the declarator, e.g.,
    5167             : 
    5168             :   int i, const j, const *k;  // Declares j as "const int", k as "int *"
    5169             : 
    5170             : This routine will see them only at the beginning of a declarator that
    5171             : is not immediately next to its specifiers list, as above, because otherwise
    5172             : the qualifiers are processed as part of the specifiers.
    5173             : 
    5174             : Type qualifiers get processing similar to that for calling conventions.
    5175             : If a pointer declarator looks like
    5176             : 
    5177             :         far * far * far
    5178             : 
    5179             : *left_qualifiers is used to return the first qualifier (but only if
    5180             : specifiers_type is NULL; otherwise, the qualifier is applied directly
    5181             : to the specifiers type); the middle qualifier is handled internally
    5182             : by applying it to the pointer type; and the last (unbound) qualifier
    5183             : is returned in *unbound_qualifiers.  If unbound_qualifiers is NULL,
    5184             : unbound qualifiers are just thrown away.
    5185             : 
    5186             : The pointer modifiers __ptr32 and __ptr64 (yet another Microsoft extension)
    5187             : are also accepted by this routine: They directly affect the type entry for the
    5188             : pointer they qualify (i.e., these are not modeled as "tk_typeref" entries).
    5189             : 
    5190             : Microsoft extended decl modifiers are also scanned, but they are ignored
    5191             : (which is what the Microsoft compiler itself appears to do).
    5192             : */
    5193             : {
    5194     3428380 :   a_type_ptr                complete_type = specifiers_type;
    5195     3428380 :   a_boolean                 err = FALSE;
    5196     3428380 :   a_pointer_modifier_state  ptr_mods;
    5197     3428380 :   a_type_ptr                class_type;
    5198     3428380 :   a_type_ptr                rout_type;
    5199             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED
    5200             :   a_pointer_modifier_state  pending_ptr_mods;
    5201             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED */
    5202     3428380 :   a_upc_block_size          upc_block_size = UPC_BLOCK_SIZE_NONE;
    5203     3428380 :   a_boolean                 ref_to_ref_allowed = TRUE;
    5204             : 
    5205     3428380 :   db_enter(3, "pointer_declarator");
    5206     3428380 :   *ptr_to_member_scanned = FALSE;
    5207             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED
    5208             :   if (ms_extensions or_near_and_far_enabled()) {
    5209             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    5210             :     /* Clear parameters used to return left/unbound qualifiers. */
    5211             :     if (left_calling_convention != NULL) {
    5212             :       clear_call_conv_descr(left_calling_convention);
    5213             :     }  /* if */
    5214             :     if (unbound_calling_convention != NULL) {
    5215             :       clear_call_conv_descr(unbound_calling_convention);
    5216             :     }  /* if */
    5217             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5218             :     if (left_qualifiers != NULL) *left_qualifiers = TQ_NONE;
    5219             :     if (unbound_qualifiers != NULL) *unbound_qualifiers = TQ_NONE;
    5220             :     /* Scan qualifiers that precede the first pointer or reference, e.g.,
    5221             :          int far *p;
    5222             :     */
    5223             :     collect_pointer_declarator_extended_qualifiers(
    5224             :                            /*ptr_op_seen=*/FALSE, /*ptr_to_member_seen=*/FALSE,
    5225             :                            &pending_ptr_mods, decl_pos_block);
    5226             :   } else {
    5227             :     clear_pointer_modifier_state(&pending_ptr_mods);
    5228             :   }  /* if */
    5229             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED */
    5230     3428380 :   clear_pointer_modifier_state(&ptr_mods);
    5231             :   /* Loop while there are pointer declarators. */
    5232      250169 :   for (;;) {
    5233             :     /* See if there is a pointer declarator. */
    5234     3678540 :     a_boolean  another_pointer_declarator = FALSE;
    5235     3678540 :     a_boolean  ptr_to_member_case = FALSE, rvalue_ref_case = FALSE;
    5236     3678540 :     a_boolean  plain_ptr = (curr_token == tok_star), managed_type = FALSE;
    5237     3678540 :     if ((plain_ptr ||
    5238      846881 :          (reference_allowed && (curr_token == tok_ampersand ||
    5239      821145 :                                 (rvalue_references_enabled &&
    5240             :                                  curr_token == tok_and_and))))) {
    5241             :       /* A pointer "*", ordinary ("lvalue") reference "&", or rvalue
    5242             :          reference "&&". */
    5243      249857 :       another_pointer_declarator = TRUE;
    5244      249857 :       if (curr_token == tok_and_and) {
    5245        2316 :         rvalue_ref_case = TRUE;
    5246        2316 :         report_gnu_cpp11_extension_if_needed(
    5247             :                               &pos_curr_token, ec_rvalue_references_is_cpp11);
    5248             :       }  /* if */
    5249     3489390 :     } else if (!C_mode() && is_ptr_to_member_declarator_start()) {
    5250             :       /* A pointer-to-member "Name::*". */
    5251         312 :       another_pointer_declarator = TRUE;
    5252         312 :       ptr_to_member_case = TRUE;
    5253         312 :       *ptr_to_member_scanned = TRUE;
    5254             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    5255             :     } else if (cli_or_cx_enabled &&
    5256             :                (curr_token == tok_excl_or || 
    5257             :                 (reference_allowed && curr_token == tok_remainder))) {
    5258             :       /* C++/CLI declarator operators "^" (handle) or "%" (tracking
    5259             :          reference). */
    5260             :       another_pointer_declarator = TRUE;
    5261             :       managed_type = TRUE;
    5262             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5263             :     }  /* if */
    5264             :     /* Exit the loop if there is not another pointer declarator. */
    5265     3678540 :     if (!another_pointer_declarator) break;
    5266      250169 :     set_err_pos_to_curr_token();
    5267             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED || NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED
    5268             :     if (pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers != TQ_NONE) {
    5269             :       /* Apply pending qualifiers to the complete type being built up, now
    5270             :          that we know those are not unbound qualifiers. */
    5271             : #if NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED
    5272             :       if ((pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers & ~(TQ_NEAR | TQ_FAR)) != TQ_NONE) {
    5273             :         /* Drop qualifiers like const/volatile because Microsoft drops
    5274             :            them:
    5275             :              int p, const *q;
    5276             :            q has type "int *", not "const int *".  The only qualifiers
    5277             :            like this that can be dropped are from the qualifiers collected
    5278             :            above before the first iteration of the loop. */
    5279             :         pos_warning(ec_type_qualifier_ignored,
    5280             :                     &pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers_pos);
    5281             :         pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers &= (TQ_NEAR | TQ_FAR);
    5282             :       }  /* if */
    5283             :       if (pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers != TQ_NONE) {
    5284             :         /* Some qualifiers like near were specified.  Apply them to
    5285             :            the complete type or (at the beginning of a nested declarator)
    5286             :            return them to the caller.  Note that qualifiers like const
    5287             :            do not get here (they're handled at the end of the loop). */
    5288             :         if (complete_type != NULL) {
    5289             :           check_for_addition_of_incompatible_qualifiers(
    5290             :                                   complete_type, &pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers,
    5291             :                                   &pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers_pos);
    5292             :           complete_type = make_qualified_type(complete_type,
    5293             :                                               pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers);
    5294             :         } else if (left_qualifiers != NULL) {
    5295             :           /* Return left-most qualifiers to the caller. */
    5296             :           *left_qualifiers = pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers;
    5297             :         }  /* if */
    5298             :         pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers = TQ_NONE;
    5299             :       }  /* if */
    5300             : #else /* !NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED */
    5301             :       pos_warning(ec_type_qualifier_ignored, &pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers_pos);
    5302             :       pending_ptr_mods.qualifiers = TQ_NONE;
    5303             : #endif /* NEAR_AND_FAR_ALLOWED */
    5304             :     }  /* if */
    5305             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED

    5699             :          pointer operator.  Issue a warning that the modifier is
    5700             :          being discarded. */
    5701             :       pos_warning(ec_based_not_followed_by_star, &pending_ptr_mods.based_pos);
    5702             :     }  /* if */
    5703             :   }  /* if */
    5704             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5705     3428380 :   db_exit();
    5706     3428380 :   return complete_type;
    5707             : }  /* pointer_declarator */
    5708             : 
    5709             : 
    5710             : #if !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED
    5711             : /*ARGSUSED*/  /* <-- opname and parent_type are unused in that case. */
    5712             : #endif /* !MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5713             : static a_boolean is_microsoft_static_operator(an_opname_kind  opname,
    5714             :                                               a_type_ptr      parent_type)
    5715             : /*
    5716             : Microsoft compilers allow most operators to be declared as static member
    5717             : functions.  In C++/CLI mode, this is true only if parent_type (the class type
    5718             : of which the operator is a member) is a managed type.  This function returns
    5719             : FALSE if and only if the operator kind opname is an exception to that rule (or
    5720             : if microsoft bugs mode and C++/CLI modes are disabled).
    5721             : */
    5722             : {
    5723             :   a_boolean  result = FALSE;
    5724             : 
    5725             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED

    5727             :     if (cli_or_cx_enabled && !is_managed_class_type(parent_type)) {
    5728             :       result = FALSE;
    5729             :     } else {
    5730             :       result = opname != (an_opname_kind)onk_assign &&
    5731             :                opname != (an_opname_kind)onk_function_call &&

    5733             :                opname != (an_opname_kind)onk_arrow;
    5734             :     }  /* if */
    5735             :   }  /* if */
    5736             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5737             :   return result;
    5738             : }  /* is_microsoft_static_operator */
    5739             : 
    5740             : 
    5741     3333270 : static void scan_id_attributes(a_decl_parse_state  *dps)
    5742             : /*
    5743             : Scan attributes following a declarator-id.  If this includes GNU attributes,
    5744             : reclassify them as appropriate (e.g., in some GNU modes, type-transforming
    5745             : attributes are applied to the underlying type).
    5746             : */
    5747             : {
    5748     3333270 :   an_attribute_ptr  attributes = scan_attributes(al_declarator_id);

    5750     3333270 :   if (attributes != NULL) {

    5752       13794 :         dps->declared_storage_class != (a_storage_class)sc_typedef) {

    5796             : #endif /* !EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */
    5797             : static void scan_real_declarator_id(
    5798             :                         a_decl_parse_state  *dps,
    5799             :                         a_decl_flag_set     input_flags,
    5800             :                         a_decl_flag_set     *output_flags,
    5801             :                         a_symbol_locator    *locator,
    5802             :                         a_boolean           *is_constructor,
    5803             :                         a_boolean           *is_static_constructor,
    5804             :                         a_boolean           *is_destructor,
    5805             :                         a_boolean           *is_finalizer,
    5806             :                         a_boolean           *parenthesized_initializer_allowed,
    5807             :                         a_boolean           *not_a_function_declarator,
    5808             :                         a_type_ptr          *p_member_parent_type,
    5809             :                         a_decl_pos_block    *decl_pos_block)
    5810             : /*
    5811             : This routine is called by declarator for real declarators; it scans the name
    5812             : that is specified (and any following attributes).  The current token is the
    5813             : beginning of the name (usually but not always an identifier).  dps points to a
    5814             : structure describing various properties of the current declaration.
    5815             : input_flags is the set of flags passed in to declarator, and *output_flags is
    5816             : the set of flags that will be returned to declarator's caller.  *locator is
    5817             : returned with the locator for the name.  *p_member_parent_type is the class
    5818             : type when this is a qualified name.  *is_constructor, *is_static_constructor,
    5819             : *is_destructor, or *is_finalizer is set to TRUE if the name is for a
    5820             : constructor, a C++/CLI static constructor, a destructor, or a finalizer
    5821             : respectively.
    5822             : *parenthesized_initializer_allowed is set to FALSE if the entity being
    5823             : declared is not initializable, and *not_a_function_declarator is set if the
    5824             : declared entity is known to not be a function.
    5825             : */
    5826             : {
    5827             :   a_source_position         declarator_pos;
    5828             :   a_boolean                 err;
    5829             :   an_identifier_options_set options;
    5830             :   a_symbol_ptr              sym;
    5831             :   a_namespace_ptr           nsp;
    5832             :   a_boolean                 is_in_class_specialization = FALSE;
    5833             :   a_boolean                 is_specialization_or_instantiation;
    5834             :   a_boolean                 is_specialization = FALSE;
    5835             :   a_boolean                 explicit_template_args_allowed = FALSE;
    5836             :   a_boolean                 template_args_allowed_only_on_func_decl = FALSE;
    5837             :   a_boolean                 ignore_explicit_template_args = FALSE;
    5838             : 
    5839             :   db_enter(3, "scan_real_declarator_id");
    5840             :   declarator_pos = pos_curr_token;
    5841             : #if EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL
    5842             :   if (decl_pos_block != NULL) {
    5843             :     decl_pos_block->identifier_range.start = pos_curr_token;
    5844             :   }  /* if */
    5845             : #endif /* EXTRA_SOURCE_POSITIONS_IN_IL */
    5846             :   /* Process the identifier.  This is done if we are at the beginning of a
    5847             :      qualified name.  A special test is done to exclude a destructor name
    5848             :      that is not part of a qualified name -- this case is handled separately
    5849             :      below.  A destructor that is not part of a qualified name (according to
    5850             :      the locator) can appear to be an identifier under some circumstances.
    5851             :      For example, inside the definition of class A, the destructor "A::~A"
    5852             :      will be coalesced by is_generalized_identifier_start.  The qualifier
    5853             :      will then be discarded by simplify_curr_class_qualified_name resulting
    5854             :      in an unqualified destructor that has already been coalesced. */
    5855             :   is_specialization_or_instantiation =
    5856             :     (input_flags & (DI_IS_SPECIALIZATION | DI_IS_EXPLICIT_INSTANTIATION)) != 0;

    5858             :   if (!(input_flags & DI_QUALIFIED_NAME_ALLOWED)) {
    5859             :     options |= GID_DISALLOW_QUALIFIED_NAME | GID_DISALLOW_GLOBAL_QUALIFIER;
    5860             :   }  /* if */
    5861             :   if (input_flags & DI_IS_TEMPLATE_DECLARATION) {
    5862             :     options |= GID_IS_TEMPLATE_DECLARATION;

    5864             :       options |= GID_IS_TEMPLATE_SPECIALIZATION;

    5867             :   }  /* if */

    5871             :   if (variable_templates_enabled &&

    5875             :        specializations.  We don't know if that is what we have now, but
    5876             :        we need to allow for that case. */
    5877             :     explicit_template_args_allowed = TRUE;
    5878             :   } else if (is_specialization_or_instantiation ||
    5879             :              (input_flags & DI_EXPLICIT_TEMPLATE_ARGS_ALLOWED) ||

    5881             :              !(options & GID_IS_TEMPLATE_DECLARATION))) {
    5882             :     explicit_template_args_allowed = TRUE;
    5883             :   } else if (microsoft_mode &&
    5884             :              depth_innermost_function_scope == NO_SCOPE_DEPTH) {
    5885             :     /* In Microsoft mode a function declarator can take explicit template
    5886             :        argument syntax.  If the declaration is not a template, it is taken to
    5887             :        be a specialization.  For example,
    5888             :          template <class T> void f(T) { ... }
    5889             :          void f<int>(int) { ... }
    5890             :        is allowed in Microsoft mode -- the second line is equivalent to
    5891             :          template <> void f<int>(int) { ... }
    5892             :        (In more recent versions of the Microsoft compiler, this is actually
    5893             :        context-dependent.  That dependency is handled elsewhere.)
    5894             :        If the declaration is a non-member template redeclaration, the template
    5895             :        argument list may simply be ignored (with a warning).  For example:
    5896             :          template <class T> void f(T);
    5897             :          template <class T> void f<float>(T) { ... }  // <float> ignored
    5898             :        Such cases are handled in higher-level declaration processing.

    5904             :       ignore_explicit_template_args = TRUE;
    5905             :     }  /* if */
    5906             :   }  /* if */

    5909             :        set, this must be a Microsoft mode in-class specialization. */
    5910             :     is_in_class_specialization = TRUE;
    5911             :   }  /* if */
    5912             :   if (is_generalized_identifier_start(GID_DTOR_RECOGNIZED) &&
    5913             :       (!is_dtor_like_locator(locator_for_curr_id) ||
    5914             :        locator_for_curr_id.is_qualified_name)) {
    5915             :     an_identifier_lookup_mode  lookup_mode = ilm_declarator;
    5916             : #if MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED

    5918             :         dps->declared_storage_class == (a_storage_class)sc_static) {
    5919             :       lookup_mode = ilm_static_declarator;

    5921             : #endif /* MICROSOFT_EXTENSIONS_ALLOWED */
    5922             :     if (any_cfront_mode()) {
    5923             :       /* Provide support for an exploitable cfront bug. */
    5924             :       if (locator_for_curr_id.is_qualified_name &&
    5925             :           qualifier_class_type(locator_for_curr_id) != NULL &&
    5926             :           input_flags & DI_IS_TYPEDEF_DECLARATION) {
    5927             :         /* We have a typedef declaration involving what appears to be a
    5928             :            qualified name, but cfront interprets it as a kind of member
    5929             :            routine type, e.g.,

    5931             :                                ^---------We're here now.
    5932             :            The type "t" is construed as a routine type taking an int argument
    5933             :            and returning void and having an implicit this-param type of
    5934             :            const-ptr-to-A.  Note that this syntax and interpretation are not
    5935             :            supported in the ARM.  We allow it under cfront compatibility mode

    5937             :         check_assertion(locator_for_curr_id.specific_symbol == NULL);

    5939             :            to the routine type. */

    5941             :         *output_flags |= DO_CFRONT_MEMBER_FUNCTION_TYPEDEF;
    5942             :         /* Clear the is_qualified_name flag in the locator, but keep the
    5943             :            qualifer_class_type around, in case this is a recursive declarator
    5944             :            call and the function_declarator is called at another level. */
    5945             :         locator_for_curr_id.is_qualified_name = FALSE;
    5946             :         /* Note that the diagnostic on this nonstandard construct is issued
    5947             :            by the caller. */
    5948             :       }  /* if */
    5949             :     }  /* if */
    5950             :     if (locator_for_curr_id.is_qualified_name) {
    5951             :       if (locator_for_curr_id.is_class_member) {
    5952             :         if (!(input_flags & DI_IS_FRIEND_DECL) || microsoft_bugs) {
    5953             :           /* If this declaration appears in the immediate context of a class
    5954             :              definition and the current token is an identifier representing
    5955             :              the name of the current class, see if this is a qualified name
    5956             :              and if so change it into a simple name (e.g., A::x becomes x,
    5957             :              its equivalent in A's scope).  This needs to be done after the
    5958             :              check for the cfront member typedef processing that is done
    5959             :              above.  Ordinarily, this does not apply to the declarator of a
    5960             :              friend declaration (i.e., "friend void A::f();" is an error in
    5961             :              class A if f had not been declared yet), but Microsoft compilers
    5962             :              perform the transformation anyway (thereby creating ::f instead
    5963             :              of A::f(!!)). */
    5964             :           if (simplify_curr_class_qualified_name() /* side effects */ &&
    5965             :               (input_flags & DI_IS_FRIEND_DECL)) {
    5966             :             /* We're emulating a Microsoft bug by ignoring the qualification
    5967             :                on a friend function (possibly injecting it in the surrounding
    5968             :                namespace scope).  This is likely unintended. */
    5969             :             pos_warning(ec_friend_qualification_ignored, &error_position);
    5970             :           }  /* if */
    5971             :         }  /* if */

    5974             :              standard. */

    5978             :                          &locator_for_curr_id.source_position);
    5979             :         }  /* if */
    5980             :       } else {
    5981             :         /* This must be a namespace-qualified name.  This is used when a
    5982             :            namespace member is redeclared (defined) outside its namespace.
    5983             :              namespace N { void f(); }
    5984             :              void N::f() { ... }
    5985             :            Strictly speaking, when the qualifier is used on a declarator that
    5986             :            appears within that namespace, it is an error -- though usually a
    5987             :            benign error:
    5988             :              namespace N { void N::f(); }       // error
    5989             :            (It is not benign, however, when the qualifier appears on the
    5990             :            declarator of a template declaration, because the entire declarator
    5991             :            is cached and rescanned during instantiations, at which point it is
    5992             :            possible that the qualifier's meaning will have changed.  The case
    5993             :            of a simple globally-qualified identifier (e.g., ::f) presents no
    5994             :            such problem.) */
    5995             :         a_scope_stack_entry_ptr  ssep = &scope_stack[depth_scope_stack];
    5996             :         a_boolean                is_template_decl = FALSE;
    5997             : 
    5998             :         if (ssep->kind == (a_scope_kind)sck_template_declaration) {
    5999             :           /* This is a template declaration. */
    6000             :           is_template_decl = TRUE;
    6001             :           ssep--;
    6002             :         } else if (gpp_mode && !clang_mode &&
    6003             :                    ((input_flags & DI_IS_FRIEND_DECL) ||
    6004             :                     (gnu_version < 40101 &&
    6005             :                      depth_innermost_function_scope != NO_SCOPE_DEPTH)) &&
    6006             :                    !locator_for_curr_id.is_template_id) {
    6007             :           /* An unqualified friend declarator would declare a member of the
    6008             :              nearest enclosing namespace scope.  GNU C++ compilers therefore
    6009             :              ignore qualifiers that refer to that scope.  If a friend
    6010             :              declaration is a qualified template-id, however, the template
    6011             :              must already have been declared in that namespace, so this
    6012             :              processing is not needed.  GCC up to version 4.1.0 also ignores
    6013             :              such qualifiers on local declarations.  For example:
    6014             :                  namespace N {
    6015             :                    void g() {
    6016             :                      double N::x;  // GCC treats this as "double x;".
    6017             :                    }
    6018             :                  }
    6019             :           */
    6020             :           ssep = &scope_stack[depth_innermost_namespace_scope];
    6021             :         }  /* if */
    6022             :         if (locator_for_curr_id.is_error) {
    6023             :           /* We can get here with a declaration like "int X::f();" where X
    6024             :              is not found or ambiguous.  An error will already have been
    6025             :              issued, so no additional diagnostic should be emitted here. */
    6026             :           check_assertion(total_errors != 0);
    6027             :         } else if (((ssep->kind == (a_scope_kind)sck_namespace ||

    6033             :           an_error_severity  severity = es_discretionary_error;
    6034             :           an_error_code      err_code;
    6035             :           a_boolean          keep_qualifier = FALSE;
    6036             :           /* The declarator name is qualified by the current namespace. */
    6037             :           if (is_template_decl && !do_dependent_name_processing &&
    6038             :               !gpp_mode &&
    6039             :               qualifier_namespace_ptr(locator_for_curr_id) != NULL) {
    6040             :             severity = es_error;
    6041             :           } else if (is_specialization_or_instantiation && !strict_ansi_mode) {
    6042             :             severity = es_remark;
    6043             :           } else if (!strict_ansi_mode) {
    6044             :             /* In nonstrict modes, the extraneous qualifier is accepted
    6045             :                provided it is for a redeclaration.  In general, we cannot
    6046             :                verify that this is a redeclaration at this point; so it has to
    6047             :                be checked later (e.g., in decl_variable or decl_routine). */
    6048             :             /* Save the symbol pointed to by the current locator so we can
    6049             :                undo the side-effect of curr_scope_id_lookup. */
    6050             :             a_symbol_ptr  prev_locator_sym =

    6053             :                     curr_scope_id_lookup(&locator_for_curr_id, IDL_NO_OPTIONS);

    6055             :             if (prev_sym != NULL && !is_tag_symbol(prev_sym) &&
